titleInfo.title: Development and Evaluation of a Novel Safety Behavior Elimination Intervention for Symptoms of Posttraumatic Stress

mods:mods.abstract: Individuals with posttraumatic stress symptoms (PTSS) have been shown to use a variety of safety behaviors to manage their distress. When used in the absence of true threat, safety behaviors serve to maintain PTSS by preventing the individual from collecting disconfirming evidence about the dangerousness of the situation. Thus, individuals with PTSS may benefit from eliminating their maladaptive safety behavior use. The current study aimed to develop and evaluate a brief, computer-based safety behavior reduction intervention, Safety Behavior Elimination for Traumatic Stress (SBETS). Seventy-four participants were recruited based on lifetime trauma exposure and elevated PTSS. Participants were randomly assigned to the SBETS condition or a physical health control condition (Modifiable Behavior Intervention [MoBI]). At the end of the intervention, participants selected two behaviors to reduce or eliminate over the coming month. Participants were sent reminders to reduce those behaviors twice a week, and treatment outcomes were assessed at two-week and one-month follow-up. Hierarchical linear regressions demonstrated significantly greater reductions in safety behavior use at two-week follow-up in the SBETS condition, as compared to MoBI. Further, individuals in the SBETS condition demonstrated significantly greater reductions in PTSS at one-month follow-up. Additionally, change in two-week safety behavior use fully mediated the relationship between treatment condition and one-month PTSS. The current study was limited by its relatively homogenous sample and brief follow-up period. Despite its limitations, results suggest that SBETS has a significant effect on safety behavior usage and PTSS, and may represent an acceptable, accessible treatment option for future trauma survivors. Additional research is needed to establish the efficacy of the SBETS intervention among diverse trauma-exposed populations.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Behavior Change, Computer-Based Treatment, PTSD, Technology, Trauma, Treatment
Norman B. Schmidt, Professor Directing Thesis; Jesse R. Cougle, Committee Member; Derek E. Nee, Committee Member.
